extractions.extraction_text: Outliers are data objects with characteristics that are considerably different than most of the other data objects in the data set.

attributes.definition: Data objects with characteristics that are considerably different than most of the other data objects in the data set.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Data points that are significantly different from the rest of the data.

extractions.extraction_text: So what is outlier? Outliers being considered they are not ordinary. They are different from others.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Outliers are defined by their distinctiveness from the majority of the data.

extractions.extraction_text: So sometimes to detect outlier from noise is kind of difficult too. So you really, really require a lot of understanding.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Distinguishing outliers from noise can be challenging and requires deep understanding.

extractions.extraction_text: And how do I know they are understanding? I don't know. So then you actually need to check your problem, understand what's the context, understand the background in order for you to make the correct hypothesis.

attributes.summary_of_insight: To correctly identify outliers, it's crucial to understand the problem context and background to form valid hypotheses.

extractions.extraction_text: You try the data to validate that hypothesis to see if that is correct or not. So that is how you try to process the data. Not just have the data and get everything out of it. Then you will find you spend a lot of GPU time trying out something that is not useful.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Validate hypotheses with data; avoid processing data without a clear objective, as it can waste computational resources.

attributes.definition: Information not being collected or attributes not being applicable to all cases.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Data points that are absent in a dataset, either because the information wasn't gathered or wasn't relevant for certain entries.

extractions.extraction_text: information not being collected (e.g., people declining to give their age and weight) and attributes not being applicable to all cases (e.g., annual income is not applicable to children).

attributes.scenario: information not being collected (e.g., people declining to give their age and weight) and attributes not being applicable to all cases (e.g., annual income is not applicable to children).
attributes.concept_link: Missing Values — illustrates reasons for missing data such as non-collection or inapplicability.

extractions.extraction_text: missing value. Okay. Missing value is one that we say for example, you do not collect the information.

attributes.definition: A value that was not collected or is not available.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Data that is absent for a particular entry or field.

extractions.extraction_text: So I'm not going to give you my age. But then, you know, I have some PhD student, he already graduate. Then he keep on guessing. Professor, I think you are this one. Is that correct? I say guess. Okay. So all you can say, maybe they are just noise. So it will be very possible that those information cannot be collected. And then there's one thing is people intentionally not try to give that to you. Or then they have something is like certain attribute. You probably there's no way for you to get that information because for example, right now you ask the children, what is their income? They don't have that. So that is, it looks like missing, but actually that missing is reasonable.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Missing values can arise from uncollected data, intentional withholding, or inherent unreasonableness (e.g., asking children for income).

extractions.extraction_text: But then, so what the part is, how can you differentiate that null supposed to be null or then null supposed to be something you need to be collected. That is the problem for missing.

attributes.summary_of_insight: The challenge with missing data is determining if a null value truly means absence or if it's a placeholder for data that should have been collected.

extractions.extraction_text: You need to also have your final, your hypothesis about that. You collect the income, then you need to thinking about the income probably, you know, there's one year we do the KTV cup and then we try to know is any black money actually being delivered from the different account from one transaction to another. How do we know that is the black money? You need to make hypothesis. For example, age. And age make difference. Yes. Because they are going to get certain fake account or some account. So the student need to do a lot of understanding behind a word. Can be exist in front of different counter at the same time or not.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Formulate hypotheses and use related attributes (like age) to infer the nature and potential reasons for missing data, especially in contexts like fraud detection.

extractions.extraction_text: For example, right now you ask the children, what is their income? They don't have that. So that is, it looks like missing, but actually that missing is reasonable.

attributes.scenario: asking children for their income, which they typically do not have.
attributes.concept_link: Missing Value — illustrates a reasonable cause for missing data

extractions.extraction_text: there's one year we do the KTV cup and then we try to know is any black money actually being delivered from the different account from one transaction to another. How do we know that is the black money? You need to make hypothesis. For example, age. And age make difference. Yes. Because they are going to get certain fake account or some account. So the student need to do a lot of understanding behind a word. Can be exist in front of different counter at the same time or not.

attributes.scenario: investigating 'black money' transactions by analyzing account transfers and using hypotheses like age to identify suspicious patterns.
attributes.concept_link: Missing Value / Hypothesis Testing — demonstrates inferring information and identifying potential issues (like fraud) by making educated guesses based on available data and context.

attributes.definition: Data that describes the location and shape of geographic features.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Information that has a geographic component, like coordinates or addresses, telling you where something is.

attributes.summary_of_insight: The type of data you need to consider is dictated by the hypothesis you are trying to prove or disprove.

extractions.extraction_text: So if you find out the evidence like this account actually show up at the different location of the ATM and about the same time, which mean they do have the gunner, right?

attributes.scenario: Finding evidence of an account at different ATM locations around the same time, suggesting a connection or coordinated activity.
attributes.concept_link: Spatial Data — illustrates how location data (ATM locations) combined with time data can support a hypothesis about coordinated actions.

text:
# LECTURE ANALYSIS: Outliers and Missing Values
## Video Segment: 134:00 - 138:28

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide discusses outliers, defining them as data objects with characteristics that are considerably different from most of the other data objects in the data set. It also shows a scatter plot with several clusters of data points and some points circled in red, presumably representing outliers.

[TRANSCRIPT - 134:00]
Outliers are data objects with characteristics that are considerably different than most of the other data objects in the data set. Noise is not sometimes not just noise because they can combine with many, many different things. And then actually they will make you to decide are they outlier or not outlier. So what is outlier? Outliers being considered they are not ordinary. They are different from others. So for right now, you can actually see for this figure. Can you identify which one are outlier? You might say professor, you already say that there's one who actually marks a red circle. Your data like this one. Right? But...

[TRANSCRIPT - 134:41]
So sometimes to detect outlier from noise is kind of difficult too. So you really, really require a lot of understanding. And how do I know they are understanding? I don't know. So then you actually need to check your problem, understand what's the context, understand the background in order for you to make the correct hypothesis. You try the data to validate that hypothesis to see if that is correct or not. So that is how you try to process the data. Not just have the data and get everything out of it. Then you will find you spend a lot of GPU time trying out something that is not useful.

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide transitions to 'Missing Values'. It lists reasons for missing values, such as information not being collected (e.g., people declining to give their age and weight) and attributes not being applicable to all cases (e.g., annual income is not applicable to children). It also has a section on handling missing values.

[TRANSCRIPT - 135:30]
Next one, missing value. Okay. Missing value is one that we say for example, you do not collect the information. So then my answer will be you guessed. For example, can I ask me professor, what is your age? Then my answer will be you guess. So I'm not going to give you my age. But then, you know, I have some PhD student, he already graduate. Then he keep on guessing. Professor, I think you are this one. Is that correct? I say guess. Okay. So all you can say, maybe they are just noise. So it will be very possible that those information cannot be collected. And then there's one thing is people intentionally not try to give that to you. Or then they have something is like certain attribute. You probably there's no way for you to get that information because for example, right now you ask the children, what is their income? They don't have that. So that is, it looks like missing, but actually that missing is reasonable. But then so what the part is, how can you differentiate that null supposed to be null or then null supposed to be something you need to be collected. That is the problem for missing. Okay. How do you know? You need to also have your final, your hypothesis about that. You collect the income, then you need to thinking about the income probably, you know, there's one year we do the KTV cup and then we try to know is any black money actually being delivered from the different account from one transaction to another. How do we know that is the black money? You need to make hypothesis. For example, age. And age make difference. Yes. Because they are going to get certain fake account or some account. So the student need to do a lot of understanding behind a word. Can be exist in front of different counter at the same time or not. So if you find out the evidence like this account actually show up at the different location of the ATM and about the same time, which mean they do have the gunner, right? And so that part require people to understand about it. How do you know about that type, you need to put in the spatial data inside. Depends on your hypothesis.
